Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Development of a Mechanistic Framework Correlating Quantum Dot Surface Chemistry and Subsurface Environmental Fate and Transport

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1505718
Goldfarb, Jillian

The interfacial interactions between quantum dots (QD) surface coatings and ecological surfaces are critical determinants of the environmental fate and transport of these materials. However, currently there is no foundational understanding of the mechanisms by which such interactions occur. Therefore it is necessary to examine and test every nanomaterial using a battery of tests to predict resulting subsurface behavior. This proposal will lay a foundation for a mechanistic understanding of the interplay between QD surface coatings and their subsurface reactions. Multivariate statistical analysis tools will be used to analyze data in a framework that reduces the experimental burden by correlating the composition of QD coatings with the environmental factors that influence nanoparticle behavior. By laying a mechanistic foundation for understanding of how QDs with varying structures respond to different environmental stimuli, the project may transform our approach to evaluating the environmental impacts of emerging nanomaterials from the test-and-observe approach to one of predict-and-verify. The long-term goal is to enable assessment of environmental impacts of manufactured nanomaterials in a combined computational and experimental framework. This is a radically different approach from the existing strategy of thoroughly test every new nanomaterial and involves an innovative methodology for developing a novel predictive tool.

Core/shell semiconductor quantum dots (QDs) are heterogeneous nanomaterials with seemingly infinite applications and unknown potential effects on human health and the environment. As QDs transition from specialized research laboratories to components in consumer and biological devices, there is a need to develop an understanding of how they will interact, persist, and degrade in the environment. The objective of this proposal is to develop an experimental framework to enable a mechanistic understanding of the relationships between QD surface characteristics and the physico-chemical properties of the subsurface environment on the agglomeration, adsorption, and partitioning of core/shell QDs. This objective will be met by synthesizing QDs with four organic coating combinations (hydrophobic interactions or dative bonding, paired with electrostatic repulsions or steric hindrance). The nanoparticles will be fully characterized to assess their size, morphology, monodispersity, concentration, quantum yield and photoluminescence, crystalline structure, ratio of core and shell atoms, and ratio of coating to particle. To develop this mechanistic understanding, the agglomeration kinetics of QDs with common soil colloids, their partitioning behavior between octanol and water, and their adsorption to saturated porous media, all as a function of ionic strength and pH, will be measured. An initial framework using multivariate statistical analysis will enable the modeling and quantification of relationships between pH and ionic strength and the partitioning, agglomeration, and adsorption for each of the four coating possibilities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Though the innumerable benefits of engineered nanomaterials such as semiconductor quantum dots (QDs) are widely touted, there is limited data on their potential effects on human health and the environment. As these nanoparticles (NPs) become widely employed in consumer and biomedical devices, it is critical to understand how they will interact, persist, and degrade in the environment. The objective of this proposal was to design an experimental framework to understand the interplay of QD characteristics and physical/chemical properties of the environment on the removal of these nanomaterials from environmentally relevant systems. 

Intellectual Merit: We developed experiments to determine the impact of water parameters such as pH, ionic strength, and presence of mineral matters (clay) on the aggregation (both QD to QD and QD to clay), and therefore removal, of QDs from water. Previous researchers have supposed that clay minerals may be a viable sorbent for the removal of quantum dot nanomaterials from aqueous solutions. However, our findings demonstrated that clay minerals are not an efficient material for retaining QDs coated with ligands that stabilize them in water. To pull QDs out of dilute aqueous solutions (to concentrate them for disposal), a more neutral or positively charged mineral may be more effective than negatively charged clays. Increasing the salt concentration or lowering the pH to induce QD aggregation would increase the treatment needed for the aqueous filtrate and may be counter-productive. With regards to QD mobility in soils, QD retention likely will result from homoaggregation following dilution-induced ligand detachment for weakly bound ligands. However, as increasingly stable QDs are developed for biomedical applications, these will also be more stable in natural environments as well and could end up being quite mobile. The development of experimental procedures to study the interactions between the QDs and the clays will allow for further study into how the nanomaterials could be removed from waste water and how we might expect the materials to move through groundwater.

Broader Impacts: This grant provided training opportunities for two undergraduate women and one female post-doctoral scholar, as well as began a new collaboration for two female junior faculty members in engineering. The PI and co-PI are continuing to collaborate to write the rest of the papers to disseminate results from this study, and have designed a new project on nano-enabled consumer projects as a direct results of this work. In addition, because of this project, PI Goldfarb was asked to sit on a new IUPAC Committee concerning standard for Environmental Nanotechnology research. One undergraduate student has gone on to graduate school for a Ph.D. in forensic chemistry, and the second will graduate with a B.S. in biomedical engineering next year. The post-doctoral fellow originally thought she wanted to pursue a career in academia, and in fact had several interviews this year, but has since realized that she would like to use her knowledge in environmental implications of emerging contaminants to pursue a career involving community-based science activism.
